name: butylcyclopentane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The compound butylcyclopentane can be thought of as the combination of a cyclopentane ring and a butyl group. The basic unit, cyclopentane, has a melting point of -94°C. Adding a butyl group (–C4H9) to the ring increases the molecular weight and surface area, leading to increased London dispersion forces between molecules, which tends to increase the melting point. However, the linear alkyl chain can also cause an increase in the flexibility of the molecule, which may slightly reduce the melting point. Estimating the contribution of the butyl group to be around -6 to -4 degrees due to these mixed effects, adjusting the baseline of cyclopentane yields a predicted melting point.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit, cyclopentane, has a melting point of -95.6°C. The addition of a butyl group increases the molecular weight and size, which typically raises the melting point due to increased van der Waals forces. However, the butyl group also introduces steric hindrance, which can disrupt the crystal lattice, potentially lowering the melting point. The effect of the butyl group on the melting point is complex and depends on the specific molecular structure and the interplay between the increase in molecular weight and the disruption of the crystal lattice.
##Prediction: -95.0
